lesson.name: Lesson 8.8: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Factored Form, Part 3

page.title: 8.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will encounter quadratic expressions without a linear term and consider how to write them in factored form. We will begin by studying numerical examples and noticing that certain expressions are equivalent.

Remember that when you want to enter a number with an exponent, use the ^ symbol. It will look like "\(x^2\)" when you want to enter \(x^2\). To make the ^ symbol, push shift and the numeral 6 at the same time.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain why multiplying binomials that are a sum and a difference, \((x + m)(x − m)\), results in a quadratic expression with no linear term.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression of the form \(x^2−c\) into its factored form.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.8.1: Evaluating Expressions Using Mental Math
  • 8.8.2: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares
    • 8.8.2: Self Check
    • 8.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.3: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term
    • 8.8.3: Self Check
    • 8.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.4: Determining if an Expression Can Be Rewritten in Factored Form

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 8.8.5: Practice
  • 8.8.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.8.1: Evaluating Expressions Using Mental Math
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Finding a product mentally can be done by changing the way you look at a multiplication problem.

For example, \(9 \cdot 39\) can be thought of as \(9 \cdot (40 − 1)\). For some people, this might be easier to calculate mentally since you can imagine the solution as \(360 − 9\), or 351. This method leverages the distributive property of multiplication over addition.

For the following questions, find each product mentally. Then, explain how you changed the way you looked at each multiplication problem to use the distributive property.

  1. \(9 \cdot 11\)

Enter the product and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

99

For example, \(9 \cdot 11\) can be thought of as \(9 \cdot (10 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(90 + 9\), or 99.


  1. \(19 \cdot 21\)

Enter the product and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

399

For example, \(19 \cdot 21\) can be thought of as \(19 \cdot (20 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(380 + 19\), or 399.


  1. \(99 \cdot 101\)

Enter the product and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

9999

For example, \(99 \cdot 101\) can be thought of as \(99 \cdot (100 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(9900 + 99\), or 9999.


  1. \(109 \cdot 101\)

Enter the product and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

11,009

For example, \(109 \cdot 101\) can be thought of as \(109 \cdot (100 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(10,900 + 109\), or 11,009.

page.title: 8.8.2: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Clare claims that \((10 + 3)(10 - 3)\) is equivalent to \(10^2-3^2\) and \((20 + 1)(20 - 1)\) is equivalent to \(20^2-1^2\). Do you agree? Show your reasoning.

Enter your answer and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

Agree.

\((10+3)(10-3)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=\left(10+3\right)\left(10+(-3)\right)\\=10^2+10\left(-3\right)+3\left(10\right)+3\left(-3\right)\\=10^2-30+30-3^2\\=10^2-3^2}\\&&\end{array}\)

\((20 + 1)(20 - 1)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=\left(20 + (-1)\right)\left(20 -1\right)\\= 20^2+ 20\left(-1\right) + 20\left(1\right) + 1\left(-1\right) \\= 20^2- 12}\\&&\end{array}\)


  1. You can use your observations from the first question to mentally solve an expression such as \(105 \cdot 95\).
  1. First, think about the problem differently. Evaluate \((100 + 5)(100 - 5)\) using the distributive property, or FOIL. Show your reasoning.

Enter your answer and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

\((100 + 5)(100 - 5) = 100^2- 5^2= 10,000 - 25 = 9975\)


  1. Check your answer by computing \(105 \cdot 95\).

Enter your answer.

Compare your answer:

\(105 \cdot 95 = 9975\)


  1. Is \((x + 4)(x - 4)\) equivalent to \(x^2-4^2\)?
  1. First, support your thinking using a diagram.
 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

    

x4

    

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Yes.

 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

x4

\(-4x\)

\(-4(4)\)


  1. Now, support your thinking using the distributive property, or FOIL.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x + 4)(x - 4)= x^2+ 4x - 4x - 4(4) = x^2- 4^2\)


  1. Is \((x + 4)^2\) equivalent to \(x^2+4^2\)? Support your answer, either with or without a diagram.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

No.
With a diagram:

 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

4

\(4x\)

\(4(4)\)

With FOIL:
\((x + 4)^2= (x + 4)(x + 4) = x^2+4x +4x +4(4) = x^2+8x +16\)
\(x^2+ 4^2 = x^2+ 16\)


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Explain how your work in the previous questions can help you mentally evaluate \(22 \cdot 18\).

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

\(22 \cdot 18\) can be written as \((20 + 2)(20 - 2)\), which is equivalent to \(202 - 22\), which is \(400 - 4\), or 396.


  1. Explain how your work in the previous questions can help you mentally evaluate \(45 \cdot 35\).

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

\(45 \cdot 35\) can be written as \((40 + 5)(40 - 5)\), which is equivalent to \(40^2-5^2\), which is \(1600 - 25\), or 1575.



Here is a shortcut that can be used to mentally square any two-digit number. Let's take \(83^2\), for example.

  • 83 is \(80 + 3\).
  • Compute \(80^2\) and \(3^2\), which gives 6400 and 9. Add these values to get 6409.
  • Compute \(80 \cdot 3\), which is 240. Double it to get 480.
  • Add 6409 and 480 to get 6889.

Try using this method to find the squares of some other two-digit numbers. (With some practice, it is possible to get really fast at this!)

  1. Explain why this method works.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Any two-digit number can be written as \(a + b\), where \(a\) is 10 times the first digit and \(b\) is the second digit. We are interested in squaring \(a + b\):

\((a + b)^2=(a + b)(a + b)\)

\(= a^2+ab +ab +b^2\) by the distributive property

\(= a^2+ 2ab +b^2\) by combining like terms

\(= a^2+b^2+2ab\) because addition is commutative


We get the \(a^2 + b^2\) from squaring \(a\) and \(b\) and adding them, and the \(2ab\) from multiplying the two values and doubling them.

page.title: 8.8.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is equivalent to \(9^2 − 6^2\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression is \((9 − 6)^2= 3^2= 9\). The original expression is \(9^2− 6^2= 81 − 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 − 6)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression is \((9 − 6)(9 − 6) = (3)(3) = 9\). The original expression is \(9^2 − 6^2= 81 − 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 − 6)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression is \((9 + 6)(9 + 6) = (15)(15) = 225\). The original expression is \(9^2− 6^2= 81 − 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 − 6)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply the expression to check. \((9 + 6)(9 − 6) = (15)(3) = 45\). The original expression is equivalent, \(9^2− 6^2= 81 − 36 = 45\). The answer is correct.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.8.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares

Example 1

Let's look at the expression \((12 + 5)(12 − 5)\). We want to determine if it is equivalent to \(12^2−5^2\).

We can use the distributive property of multiplication over addition, or FOIL process, to multiply.

\((12 + 5)(12 − 5)\)

\(\begin{array}{rcl} &=&12^2-12\left(5\right)+5\left(12\right)-5^2\\&&\\&=&12^2-60+60-5^2\\&&\\&=&12^2-5^2\\&&\end{array}\)
So, \((12 + 5)(12 − 5)\) is equivalent to \(12^2-5^2\).

Example 2

Let's look at a different example using a variable.

\((x + 7)(x − 7)\)

Is this equivalent to \(x^2−7^2\)?

\((x + 7)(x − 7)\)

\(\begin{array}{rcl} &=&x^2-7x+7x-7^2\\&&\\&=&x^2-7^2=x^2-49\\&&\end{array}\)
This can also be shown using a diagram.

 

\(x\)

–7

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-7x\)

7

\(7x\)

\(-7(7)\)

You have studied this process earlier when you learned the difference of squares.

In this lesson, we will reverse this process to rewrite the standard form of a quadratic expression into its factored form.

It is important to remember the linear term, or middle term of a quadratic trinomial, equals zero only holds true for the difference of squares. It does not work for an expression such as \(x^2+25\). (In fact, there is no way to multiply two binomials that would result in this expression.)

Example 3

Is \((x + 5)^2\) equivalent to \(x^2+25\)?

Let's find the equivalent expression for \((x + 5)^2\) or \((x + 5)(x + 5)\).

\(\begin{array}{rcl}\left(x+5\right)^2&=&\left(x+5\right)\left(x+5\right)\\&&\\&=&x^2+5x+5x+25\\&&\\&=&x^2+10x+25\\&&\end{array}\)
Since \(x^2+ 10x + 25\) is not equivalent to \(x^2+25\), these expressions are not the same.

Try It: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares

  1. Is the expression \((8 − 7)(8 + 7)\) equivalent to the expression \(8^2−7^2\)? Show your reasoning using the distributive property, or FOIL.
  1. Is \((x + 4)(x + 4)\) equivalent to \(x^2+ 4^2\)? Support your answer with a diagram.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to recognize the expanded product of the difference of two squares:

  1. Yes. Here is how to use the difference of squares to show equivalency between the expressions:

\((8 − 7)(8 + 7) = 8^2+ 56 − 56 − 7^2= 8^2 − 7^2\)

  1. No. The expressions are not equivalent.
 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

4

\(4x\)

\(4(4)\)

\((x + 4)(x + 4) = x^2 + 8x + 4^2 = x^2 + 8x + 16\)

It is not equivalent to \(x^2 + 4^2 = x^2 + 16\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.8.3: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term
page.contents:
Activity

In questions 1 and 2, each row of the table contains a pair of equivalent expressions.

  1. Convert the factored form expression to the standard form.

If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram.

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 10)(x + 10)\)

  

\((2x + 1)(2x − 1)\)

  

\((4 − x)(4 + x)\)

  

\((c + \frac{2}{5})(c − \frac{2}{5})\)

  

\((x + 5)(x + 5)\)

  

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 10)(x + 10)\)

\(x^2 − 100\)

\((2x + 1)(2x − 1)\)

\(4x^2− 1\)

\((4 − x)(4 + x)\)

\(16 − x^2\)

\((c + \frac {2}{5})(c − \frac {2}{5})\)

\(c^2 − \frac {4}{25}\)

\((x + 5)(x + 5)\)

\(x^2+ 10x + 25\)

  1. Convert the standard form expression to the factored form.

If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram. (HINT: One of the expressions does not convert.)

Factored form

Standard form
 

\(x^2 − 81\)
 

\(49 − y^2\)
 

\(9z^2 − 16\)
 

\(25t^2− 81\)
 

\(\frac {49}{16} − d^2\)
 

\(x^2− 6\)
 

\(x^2 + 100\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 9)(x + 9)\)

\(x^2 − 81\)

\((7 − y)(7 + y)\)

\(49 − y^2\)

\((3z + 4)(3z − 4)\)

\(9z^2 − 16\)

\((5t + 9)(5t − 9)\)

\(25t^2− 81\)

\((\frac {7}{4} − d)(\frac {7}{4} + d)\)

\(\frac {49}{16} − d^2\)

\((x − \sqrt{6})(x + \sqrt{6})\)

\(x^2− 6\)

prime

\(x^2 + 100\)


Video: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term

Watch the following video to learn more about factoring a quadratic equation that is written in standard form and has no linear term.

page.title: 8.8.3: Self Check
page.contents: Find the factored form of the expression \(16p^2 − 49\).

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply the factored form to check. \((4p + 7)(4p − 7) = 16p^2−28p +28p −49 = 16p^2− 49\). The answer is correct.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \((4p + 7)(4p + 7) = 16p^2+56p +49\). Look for the binomials that lead to the middle terms canceling each other out because they are opposites. The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \((4p − 7)(4p − 7) = 16p^2−56p +49\). Look for the binomials that lead to the middle terms canceling each other out because they are opposites. The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \(p(16p − 49) = 16p^2− 49p\). The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term

We can use what we have learned in the previous lesson to write quadratic equations of a special form into factored form.

Particularly, we can rewrite:

\(x^2− c^2\) into \((x + c)(x − c)\).

Let's look at an example.

Example 1

Write \(v^2−36\) in factored form.

We know that the form we are looking for is \((v\; −\) __ \()(v \;+\) __ \()\).

Since we know the square root of \(v^2\) is \(v\) and the square root of 36 is 6, the factored form is \((v − 6)(v + 6)\).

We can multiply to check our work.

\((v − 6)(v + 6)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=v^2+6v-6v-36\\=v^2-36\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

The process is similar when there is a coefficient on the squared term.

\(a^2x^2−c^2\;\;\;\;\) factors into \(\;\;\;\;(ax + c)(ax − c)\)

Let's look at another example to understand the process.

Example 2

Write \(16m^2− 81\) in factored form.

The form we are looking for now is ( __ − __ )( __ + __ ).

Taking the square root of the first term gives us \(4m\).

So, we have \((4m\; −\) __ \()(4m\; +\) __ \()\).

Now, we are in the same place as in the previous example. The square root of 81 is 9.

So, the factored form is \((4m − 9 )(4m + 9)\).

Again, we can multiply to check.

\((4m − 9)(4m + 9)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{= 4m^2 + 36m − 36m − 81\\= 4m^2 − 81\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

Example 3

As we see in the activity, where the variable is located is not important as long as the quadratic binomial is still the difference of two squares.

Write \(64 − 9b^2\) in factored form.

We use the same concept to find the factored form.

\(64 − 9b^2= (8 − 3b)(8 + 3b)\)

We can multiply to check.

\((8 − 3b)(8 + 3b)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{= 64 + 24b − 24b − 9b^2\\= 64 − 9b^2\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

Remember that any expression of the form \(x^2 + c\) or \(ax^2+ c\) does not have a factored form!

  • For \(x^2+ c\), the \(c\) is not squared, and the terms are not being subtracted.
  • For \(ax^2+ c\), neither the \(a\) nor the \(c\) is a perfect square, and the terms are not being subtracted.

Try It: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term


  1. Write \(x^2− 4\) in factored form.
  1. Write \(100x^2− 121\) in factored form.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write the expressions in factored form.

  1. \((x − 2)(x + 2)\)
  1. \((10x − 11)(10x + 11)\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.8.4: Determining if an Expression Can Be Rewritten in Factored Form
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Write each expression in factored form. If it is not possible, write "not possible."

  1. \(a^2− 36\)

Enter the factored form of the expression, if possible.

Compare your answer:

\((a + 6)(a − 6)\)


  1. \(49 − 25b^2\)

Enter the factored form of the expression, if possible.

Compare your answer:

\((7 + 5b)(7 − 5b)\)


  1. \(c^2+ 9\)

Enter the factored form of the expression, if possible.

Compare your answer:

Not possible because this is the sum of two squares.


  1. \(\frac {100}{81}-16d^2\)

Enter the factored form of the expression, if possible.

Compare your answer:

\((\frac {10}{9} + 4d)(\frac {10}{9} − 4d)\)

page.title: 8.8.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(10^2−12^2\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((10 + 12)(10 − 12)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 2–10, select the expression in factored form.

  1. \(c^2 − 25\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((c − 5)(c + 5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(9w^2 − 121\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((3w − 11)(3w + 11)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(h^2− 121\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((h − 11)(h + 11)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(64 − d^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((8 − d)(8 + d)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4b^2 − 25\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((2b − 5)(2b + 5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(49 − 81z^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((7 − 9z)(7 + 9z)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(100y^2−4\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((10y − 2)(10y + 2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+9\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is not possible. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(144 − 16g^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 8.8.3 and 8.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((12 − 4g)(12 + 4g)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.8.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain why multiplying binomials that are a sum and a difference, \((x + m)(x − m)\), results in a quadratic expression with no linear term.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression of the form \(x^2− c\) into its factored form.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.8.1: Evaluating Expressions Using Mental Math
    • In this activity, you learned shortcuts to performing mental math that provided insight into strategies for factoring quadratic expressions.
  • 8.8.2: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares
    • In this activity, you learned to reverse the process using the difference of squares to find the factored form of particular quadratic expressions.
    • 8.8.2: Self Check
    • 8.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.3: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term
    • In this activity, you continued to practice finding the factored form of quadratic expressions using the difference of squares. You also learned that some binomials of the form \(x^2+c\) do not have a factored form.
    • 8.8.3: Self Check
    • 8.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.4: Determining if an Expression Can Be Rewritten in Factored Form
    • In this activity, you determined whether a quadratic expression was factorable before finding its factored form using the skills learned in this lesson.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.8.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
